titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid to Anna Hempstead Branch papers MRBC.MS.00018
titlestmt.author: Ellice Amanna

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-10-25 14:26:14 -0400.

did.abstract: Anna Hempstead Branch (1875-1937) was an American poet who editor William Thomas Stead called "the Browning of American poetry. She was a member of the 1897 Smith College graduating class. The Anna Hempstead Branch Papers consist of aproximately 13 linear ft. and are primarily related to her professional and public life. The papers are arranged in nine series

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Anna Hempstead Branch papers were donated to the Mortimer Rare Book Room of Smith College by Branch's cousin, Ethel Lyman, before she died in 1946. Judge Oliver W. Branch, a cousin of Anna Hempstead Branch and of Ethel Lyman, sent additional papers to the Mortimer Rare Book Room in 1947.

Additional papers to the Branch collection were donated by Caroline M. Fuller (Smith College Class of 1895) in 1945; by Mrs. Richard Mansfield in 1945; by the Smith College Class of 1897 in 1944, and by Caroline R. Wing (possibly Smith College Class of 1896) in 1948.
Other additions were contributed by Ruth Newcomb, 1952-1959, and Winifred G. Whiton (Smith College Class of 1921), 1958.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Anna Hempstead Branch (1875-1937) was an American poet who editor William Thomas Stead called "the Browning of American poetry. She was a member of the 1897 Smith College graduating class. The year after her graduation her poem "The Road 'Twixt Heaven and Hell" was selected as the year's best verse by a college graduate by Century Magazine. Sonnets from a Lock Box (1929), a collection of thirty-eight first person sonnets is noted for its directness and mystical symbolism and is regarded as her best work.

Branch was known for her philanthropy, particularly in support of Chrstodora House, a New York City settlement house. She created the Poet's Guild whose members, including Robert Frost and Sara Teasdale, taught classes there. Branch died of cancer in 1937 at the age of 62.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: The Anna Hemstead Branch papers, Morimer Rare Book Collection, MS 18, Smith College Special Collections, Northampton, Massachusetts

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection is unprocessed, the extents are approximate, finding aid is incomplete

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Anna Hempstead Branch Collection, Connecticut College, New London, Connecticut.
Papers of the Christodora House, New York, New York. Branch had a long association with this New York settlement house. At Columbia University, New York.
Correspondence from Anna Hempstead Branch to Edwin Markham and Anna Catherine Markham in the Markham Manuscript Collection, Wagner College, Staten Island, New York.
Anna Hempstead Branch poems, circa 1910-1927. The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley.
Anna Hempstead Branch, Manuscripts, 1924-1933, and n.d. Special Collections Department, University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Virginia. Part of the Clifton Waller Barrett Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Anna Hempstead Branch Papers consist of aproximately 13 linear ft. and are primarily related to her professional and public life. The papers are arranged in nine series:
The correspondence is divided into subseries as noted below. There are still letters among some of the papers yet to be sorted, especially in the large brown box number 8.

Writings are largely contained in the large brown boxes number 3-7? and there are some in box 8. Possibly also place "reviews" of Branch's writings as a separate series or at the end of this series. In the preliminary outline Series II was noted as Branch's personal papers. Use what is appropriate once arrangement is completed.
In the preliminary outline this was listed as a possibility. Some scrapbooks were included in the Correspondence as that appeared to be more applicable. Possibly not use this designation.
IV. ORGANIZATIONAL PAPERS OF ALLIED FAMILIES, CHRISTODORS HOUSE AND POETRY GUILD
Scattered throughout the papers, possibly just put in Miscellaneous as a file or two.
VI. BRANCH AND BOLLES FAMILY DOCUMENTS

In the large brown box 8, there is a genealogy (oversize document/notebook) of the Hempstead/Branch/Bolles (?) families. Possibly there are more documents. Might consider placing this in Miscellaneous as it might only be a file or two.
VII. PUBLICATIONS OF ANNA HEMPSTEAD BRANCH
Possibly consider placing this series as III or IV following the manuscripts of her writings and notebooks and scrapbooks.

There are photographs scattered in numerous boxes. Some are identified; some not In the large brown box 8, there is a loose-leaf album (highly acidic paper) that likely should be disassembled and the individual photographs placed in protective envelopes and filed here.
Use for oversize (possibly) items. Also there is a birch box that needs to be housed that apparently was made by Anna Hempstead Branch.

Among the items to go here are recent publications in related to the Hempstead House. There are older postcards, but also booklets, pamphlets and the like that are related to the House. Most of this material is in the large brown box 8.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Anna Hempstead Branch papers are the physical property of the Mortimer Rare Book Room, Smith College. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors of the works or their legal representatives.

The Papers are open to research according to the regulations of the Mortimer Rare Book Room without any additional restrictions. Permission must be obtained to publish reproductions or quotations beyond "fair use." Copyright to materials authored by others may be owned by those individuals or their heirs or assigns. It is the responsibility of the researcher to identify and satisfy the holders of all copyrights. Permission to publish reproductions or quotations beyond "fair use" must also be obtained from the Sophia Smith Collection as owners of the physical property.
Please cite the Papers as follows: Anna Hempstead Branch Papers, Mortimer Rare Book Room, Smith College, Northampton, Mass.
This collection has not been fully processed and therefore may be difficult to use.
